ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Good philosophical background of the problems in QM.
I learned a ton about quantum mechanics and the different interpretations of what governs our world today
I learnt a great deal about the philosophy of quantum mechanics! This course was a little technical which I enjoyed!
This was a great course where I was introduced to many new concepts in quantum mechanics.

This class was a great introduction to topics in the philosophy of quantum physics. Not only did I learn more about quantum mechanics than I learned in my quantum computing class, this class was also a great exercise in philosophical argument. I gained skills as reasoning through difficult epistemological an ontological questions as well as approaching difficult texts.

A deeper than expected understanding of quantum mechanics. Students were taught the basics of linear algebra, and many of the explanations for the various interpretations of quantum mechanics required an understanding of the math.
Excellent introduction to the philosophy of quantum mechanics! A digestible presentation of the necessary physics/math to effectively discuss the philosophy.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was structured extremely well!
Too much math, but balanced by interesting philosophy papers.

A difficulty of this course is the wide range of experiences with quantum mechanics in the class. To the classes credit, one of the strengths of the class was the clarity with which the difficult material was explained to get everyone up to speed. I feel like the instructor truly did the best job that could possibly get done bring people up to speed, but I think by virtue of the subject matter, the different levels of confidence makes discussions difficult.

Strengths: Professor evidently cares about the subject material. Encouraged student engagement and collaboration. Work wasn't burdensome, and was typically engaging.
Weaknesses: If you are a pure philosophy major, the material can be tough to understand at a deeper level. But everything was accessible depending on how much time you put in.

strengths: incredibly well-organized, well-presented, good balance of types of readings and selection of readings
weaknesses: honestly hard to think of any, but it may be nice to foster more class discussions early on to get the culture rolling. I know it can be hard to get college kids to contribute, so it's useful to start early with discussions of simpler topics before things get complicated so that students have the chance to get comfortable talking.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, very interesting and well taught.
Yes it was an amazing course for people new to this type of material, highly recommend
I would definitely recommend this course as long as you arent afraid of some technical stuff!
Yes! If you credit/d

I would definitely recommend this class to anyone who is interested in the philosophy of science. I would also highly recommend this class to any research oriented physicist as the class makes the case for thinking about the philosophical stakes of theories and how that should inform future experimentation.
Yes! The subject matter was super interesting and although it's very complex, it is presented in a really acceptable way.
Yes. The subject is extremely interesting, and I particularly encourage philosophy majors to look into this course.
absolutely! I loved this course, and there isn't any other course like this at Yale.
